page.title: 01Gosberton Clough
page.content: The land surrounding Gosberton Clough is very, very flat, few trees and few houses. The hamlet of Gosberton Clough, has no shop or pub, but there is a Primary School, roll about 60, the children are bussed to the school from the surrounding country-side. Most of the residents are small farmers and their families, nearly all the land is arable, crops grown, wheat, barley, sugar-beet, potatoes, onions, vegetables and some bulbs (daffodils and tulips). In the very isolated areas houses are deserted and stand empty. Drainage in this region is very important to the farmers, dykes seperate the fields and carry the surplus water out to the wash. There is a small church and a chapel and good community spirit, also a flourishing Young Farmer's Club. Some of the houses are sold to people from
